nodes.text: Human capacity for processing simple perceptual information is limited: unidimensional absolute judgments are bounded at about seven categories (plus or minus two), and this bottleneck can be characterized and partially overcome using information-theoretic concepts

Unidimensional absolute judgments show a consistent channel capacity in the range of about 1.6 to 3.9 bits (mean about 2.6 bits), corresponding roughly to 3 to 15 discriminable categories with a mean near 6.5
Information theory provides a framework for measuring stimulus variance as bits and transmitted information as input-output covariance, enabling comparison across stimulus types without metric units

Pollack's absolute-pitch frequency identification experiment: transmitted information rises with number of tones then asymptotes at about 2.5 bits, implying about six perfectly discriminable pitch categories
Garner's loudness experiments: channel capacity about 2.3 bits, implying about five discriminable loudness categories
Taste intensity (salt concentration) measurements: channel capacity about 1.9 bits, implying about four discriminable concentration levels

Visual position and related measures give higher unidimensional capacities (position in interval about 3.25 bits; best unidimensional measures range up to 3.9 bits), indicating up to 10-15 discriminable positions

Adding independently variable dimensions to stimuli increases channel capacity, but the increase is subadditive: total capacity grows with dimensionality but less than the sum of single-dimension capacities

Pollack and Ficks multidimensional auditory experiment: six acoustic variables each at five values produced transmitted information of 7.2 bits (about 150 identifiable categories), showing large capacity increases with multiple dimensions
Klemmer and Frick dot-in-square (two-dimensional) experiment: channel capacity 4.6 bits (about 24 positions), larger than one-dimensional position but less than the perfect additive prediction
Immediate memory (span) is limited by the number of chunks (about seven items), which is a different constraint from the bits limit that governs absolute judgment

Hayes and Pollack experiments: memory span varies little with bits per item (binary digits span ~9, decimal digits ~8, monosyllabic words ~5); Pollack found transmitted information in memory spans increases roughly with bits per item, contradicting a constant-bits hypothesis
Recoding (grouping input into larger chunks) increases bits per chunk and thereby extends immediate memory span; recoding requires learning and sometimes automatic translation to be fully effective

Smith recoding experiment: grouping binary digits into octal or larger named chunks after practice increased the number of binary digits recalled (with extensive practice reaching recalls of about 40 binary digits), demonstrating practical extension of span by recoding

Conclusion: three practical ways to overcome the informational bottleneck are (a) make relative rather than absolute judgments, (b) increase stimulus dimensionality (simultaneous multiple attributes), and (c) use successive judgments plus recoding and chunking (memory sequences)

Limitations and open questions: exceptional performers (e.g., absolute-pitch musicians) exceed typical capacities; the possible upper limit on perceptual dimensionality (speculated near ten) and the causes of language phoneme dimensionality remain untested and warrant further experiments
